title: expect_with minitest and skip
body:
If you use `expect_with :minitest`, you can't use `skip` anymore -- you wind up with Minitest's `skip` implementation, which is not compatible with rspec_core's. 

``` ruby
require 'rspec'

RSpec.configure do |config|
  config.expect_with :minitest
end

RSpec.describe "an example" do
  it "skips" do
    skip "because we want to"
  end
end
```

We get a failure on the Minitest::Skip exception raised by Minitest's implementation of `skip`:

```
Failures:

  1) an example skips
     Failure/Error: skip "because we want to"
     Minitest::Skip:
       because we want to
     # ./minitest_skip.rb:9:in `block (2 levels) in <top (required)>'
```

We wanted instead:

```
Pending:
  an example skips
    # because we want to
    # ./minitest_skip.rb:8
```

Should `skip` be available even if you are `expect_with :minitest`?  I think it ought to. 

I could prepare a PR, but I'm not really sure the right/desired way to handle this. 

I guess rspec could make sure to include/extend RSpec::Core::Pending in _after_ whatever is specified in `expect_with`, to make sure rspec-core's own `skip` "wins" in the call chain. 

Or, perhaps it's okay this doesn't work, you still can skip by declaring the example with skip metadata instead -- `it "skips", :skip => true`.  Maybe that's good enough. But I just thought of/discovered the metadata-based skip just now writing this issue, after some hours of trying to figure out what was going on and why and how to get skip to work -- perhaps it should be mentioned in the docs somewhere around `expect_with :minitest`.
